title.narrative: (Re)construction 4 a Better Future

description.narrative:
The proposed project must contribute to the following long-term impact:
- (Re)construction process after Cyclone IDAI, through direct support of affected families in the Sofala province.
- People use safe drinking water and adequate sanitary facilities.
​

Tropical Cyclone IDAI made landfall with strong winds between 180 and 220 km and heavy rains of 200mm in 24 hours (source: INGC), in central Mozambique on 14th of March 2019. At the same time, owing to the heavy rains, the river Buzi and Revue achieved maximum alert and the dam at Chicamba had to be opened causing massive floods in most areas of the Buzi and Nhamatanda districts. An estimated 1.7 million people across Mozambique have been affected (source: WFP) and according to the International Organisation for Migration (10th April 2019) 240,000 houses (source: IOM) have been identified as partially or totally destroyed.
Although there has been a strong response through international organisations, such as
World Food Program, UNICEF and Red Cross, as well as from the government of Moçambique through INGC - Instituto National de Gestão de Calamidades, the numbers of effected people by the cyclone IDAI are absolutely overwhelming.
The latest official information (10th April 2019) released by INGC noted that just within the proposed district for this intervention, namely Beira and Dondo, approximately 603,000 people have been identified as affected by cyclone IDAI.
Young Africa Beira located at the Bairro of Manga, Nova Chamba (Administration post of Inhamizua) will work with affected families in the neighborhoods of Manga and Inhamizua. Young Africa Agri-Tech in Dondo, located in the neighborhood of Macharote will work with the affected families around the Centre in Macharote.
For the identification of the affected families and their respective houses, Young Africa, will work with both the “Chefes de Bairro” that are elected by the municipality and Community Leaders that are elected by the community itself. Both, the “Chefes de Bairro” as well as the community leaders are currently supporting activities of identifying the most affected families for their support.
As Young Africa Mozambique (YAM) wants to avoid any duplicate support, YAM will provide the list of identified families to the local government and ensure that they have not already been identified for reconstruction support by other organisations or the government.
Young people have lacked access to affordable, practical TVET training, already before Cyclone IDAI has hit the central region of Mozambique, as it is one solution to youth employment in Mozambique. Now, after Cyclone IDAI, where many affected families come exactly from a socially and economically disadvantaged background, the decision to send your children to vocational Training has been made even more difficult what has created a even higher need for the provision of scholarships.
YAM follows a strict internal selection process. 1. An interview with the potential beneficiary 2. A visit to the household of the potential beneficiary (by 2 YAM staff members) to ensure the information provided is correct (i.e housing type, ascertain access to water, electricity, number of people in household, number of dependents etc.) A report, with a recommendation, on both the personal interview and home visit is prepared by the Programme Officer and presented to the Director for a final decision.
YAM proposes to implement the reconstruction team in 2 phases – the first phase will consist of the disbursement of 200 scholarships: 70 Civil Construction, 50 Carpentry, 50 Electrical Installation, 30 Plumbing. The beneficiaries will be divided into groups consisting of 3-4 Civil Construction students, 2 Carpentry Students, 2 Electrical Installations, 2 Plumbing. Each group~~s~~ will have different time sets at a house during the construction phase. After the first month of theoretical lessons, the reconstruction teams are expected to start their practical lessons. The first disbursement of scholarships will construct at least 40 houses, after this there will be a second group of scholarship disbursement of another 200 scholarships that will follow the same model then the first one.

Young Africa Beira (est. 2006) is an inclusive youth empowerment organisation. The organisation focuses on the holistic development of underprivileged youths aged between 15 and 25 years with a special focus on young women and youths with disabilities. The main activities of YAM is integral skills training for (self-)employability Therefore, YAM delivers at its Technical Vocational and Education Training (TVET) - Center skills training through an innovative franchise business model (UNEVOC-UNESCO endorsed best practice training model). The sustainable integral approach addresses the multi-dimensional nature of development needs (ie. economic, social and emotional) of young people in a highly synchronized way. Young people receive on-the-job vocational training (70% practical, 30% theory), life skills and English education as well as entrepreneurship, IT training. YAM is a locally registered non-for-profit Association and deliver training in over 40 courses (Industrial, Commercial and Agricultural) in 2 locations in the districts of Beira and Dondo. Since **2007** Young Africa Beira has trained 15.500 disadvantage youth and monitored the economic and social impact of its programs.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database
